title: 103_s2515
content:
The "Fairness in Musical Licensing Act of 1994" is cited as the short title. It amends Section 110(5) of title 17, United States Code, regarding the communication of a transmission embodying a performance or display of a work in commercial establishments. SEC. 3. BINDING ARBITRATION OF RATE DISPUTES INVOLVING PERFORMING RIGHTS SOCIETIES; ACCESS TO REPERTOIRE. Section 504 of title 17, United States Code, is amended to include a new subsection allowing for binding arbitration between music users and performing rights societies to determine fair fees for music performances. In cases of infringement involving licensed musical works, the defendant can admit prior use. In cases of infringement involving licensed musical works, a performing rights society can request court annexed arbitration to determine fair fees for music performances. The arbitrator will decide the full amount owed by the defendant for past use of music, not exceeding a fair and reasonable license fee. Additionally, the arbitrator may determine a fair fee for music performance using part of the licensed music for up to 5 years. Performing rights societies and organizations must provide free online access to their music repertoires, including details like the title of the work, author information, copyright status, and artists who performed the work. Additionally, certain actions related to music licensing disputes must be referred to arbitration under the amended Section 652 of title 28, United States Code. Actions for infringement of the right granted in section 106(4) of title 17 involving a licensed nondramatic musical work by a performing rights society may be referred to arbitration if the defendant disputes the license fee demanded. Each district court must establish procedures for arbitration under this subsection. SEC. 4. PER PROGRAMMING PERIOD LICENSE. Section 504 of title 17, United States Code is amended to include a new subsection (e) regarding Period Licenses for nondramatic musical works licensed by performing rights societies. This amendment requires performing rights societies to offer per programming period licenses to radio or television broadcasters upon request, with pricing components for incidental and feature performances. The price of the license should not exceed the fee for blanket licenses. The fee for incidental public performances by broadcasters must be no higher than a blanket license fee and directly proportional to the broadcaster's actual use of the society's repertoire. The value of such uses and the relative value assigned by the performing rights society for incidental public performances should be reflected in the fee. Nondramatic musical compositions licensed directly or constituting fair use are not considered in calculating the license fee. SEC. 5. ACCESS TO REPERTOIRE.

Performing rights societies must provide free online access to their entire musical repertoire, including work title, author information, and artist performances.

SEC. 6. ANNUAL REPORT. SEC. 6. ANNUAL REPORT.

The Antitrust Division of the Department of Justice must submit an annual report to Congress by March 1 detailing its supervision and enforcement activities regarding performing rights societies. This includes issues raised, complaints filed, and actions taken in response. SEC. 7. CONFORMING AMENDMENT. Section 101 of title 17, United States Code, is amended to define a 'performing rights society' as an entity that licenses public performance of musical works on behalf of copyright owners. This includes organizations like ASCAP, BMI, and SESAC.
